This command marks the buffer as modified, since it does not (as far as Emacs knows) match the contents of <var>filename</var>, even if it matched the former visited file. It also renames the buffer to correspond to the new file name, unless the new name is already in use.

This command marks the current buffer as unmodified, and not needing to be saved. If arg is non-nil, it marks the buffer as modified, so that it will be saved at the next suitable occasion. Interactively, arg is the prefix argument.

This command marks the current location of point as the beginning of an abbrev. The next call to expand-abbrev will use the text from here to point (where it is then) as the abbrev to expand, rather than using the previous word as usual.
This command moves point backward arg lines and then to the first nonblank character on that line. It returns nil. If arg is omitted or nil, it defaults to 1.
This command moves point forward arg lines and then to the first nonblank character on that line. It returns nil. If arg is omitted or nil, it defaults to 1.
This command moves point to the first non-whitespace character in the current line (which is the line in which point is located). It returns nil.

This command performs abbrev expansion if Abbrev mode is enabled and the inserted character does not have word-constituent syntax. (See Abbrevs, and Syntax Class Table.) It is also responsible for calling blink-paren-function when the inserted character has close parenthesis syntax (see Blinking).

This command performs several complex steps to find a window to display in. These steps are described by means of display actions, which have the form (functions . alist). Here, functions is either a single function or a list of functions, referred to as “action functions” (see Buffer Display Action Functions); and alist is an association list, referred to as “action alist” (see Buffer Display Action Alists). See The Zen of Buffer Display, for samples of display actions.
This command pops up a window displaying a help buffer containing a listing of all of the key bindings from both the local and global keymaps. It works by calling describe-bindings.
This command provides help for the current mode. It prompts the user in the minibuffer with the message ‘

This command puts buffer-or-name at the end of the buffer list, without changing the order of any of the other buffers on the list. This buffer therefore becomes the least desirable candidate for other-buffer to return. The argument can be either a buffer itself or the name of one.
This command puts a charset text property on the decoded text. The value of the property states the character set used to decode the original text.

This command quits window and buries its buffer. The argument window must be a live window and defaults to the selected one. With prefix argument kill non-nil, it kills the buffer instead of burying it. It calls the function quit-restore-window described next to deal with the window and its buffer.
This command reads input and specifies a prefix argument for the following command. Don’t call this command yourself unless you know what you are doing.

This command reads the defun containing point, compiles it, and evaluates the result. If you use this on a defun that is actually a function definition, the effect is to install a compiled version of that function.
This command recompiles every ‘

This command reindents the current line, inserts a newline at point, and then indents the new line (the one following the newline just inserted). It does indentation on both lines by calling indent-according-to-mode.
This command renames the file <var>filename</var> as <var>newname</var>.

This command replaces buffer-or-name with some other buffer, in all windows displaying it. buffer-or-name should be a buffer, or the name of an existing buffer; if omitted or nil, it defaults to the current buffer.
This command replaces any spaces and tabs around point with a single space, or n spaces if n is specified. It returns nil.
This command replaces the buffer text with the text of the visited file on disk. This action undoes all changes since the file was visited or saved.
This command replaces the just-yanked entry from the kill ring with a different entry from the kill ring.

This command replaces the minibuffer contents with the value of the nth more recent history element. The position in the history can go beyond the current position and invoke “future history” (see Text from Minibuffer).
This command replaces the minibuffer contents with the value of the <var>n</var>th next (newer) history element that completes the current contents of the minibuffer before the point.
This command replaces the minibuffer contents with the value of the <var>n</var>th next (newer) history element that matches <var>pattern</var> (a regular expression).
This command replaces the minibuffer contents with the value of the <var>n</var>th previous (older) history element that completes the current contents of the minibuffer before the point.
This command replaces the minibuffer contents with the value of the <var>n</var>th previous (older) history element that matches <var>pattern</var> (a regular expression).
This command replaces the minibuffer contents with the value of the <var>n</var>th previous (older) history element.
This command returns t if there were no errors and nil otherwise. When called interactively, it prompts for the file name.

This command runs a garbage collection, and returns information on the amount of space in use. (Garbage collection can also occur spontaneously if you use more than gc-cons-threshold bytes of Lisp data since the previous garbage collection.)

This command saves some modified file-visiting buffers. Normally it asks the user about each buffer. But if save-silently-p is non-nil, it saves all the file-visiting buffers without querying the user.
This command selects a buffer visiting the file filename, but does so in a window other than the selected window. It may use another existing window or split a window; see Switching Buffers.
This command selects a buffer visiting the file filename, like find-file, but it marks the buffer as read-only. See Read Only Buffers, for related functions and variables.

This command selects a buffer visiting the file <var>filename</var>, using an existing buffer if there is one, and otherwise creating a new buffer and reading the file into it. It also returns that buffer.

This command sets the value of the environment variable named variable to value. variable should be a string. Internally, Emacs Lisp can handle any string. However, normally variable should be a valid shell identifier, that is, a sequence of letters, digits and underscores, starting with a letter or underscore. Otherwise, errors may occur if subprocesses of Emacs try to access the value of variable. If value is omitted or nil (or, interactively, with a prefix argument), setenv removes variable from the environment. Otherwise, value should be a string.

This command shows a list of shadowed Emacs Lisp files. A shadowed file is one that will not normally be loaded, despite being in a directory on load-path, due to the existence of another similarly-named file in a directory earlier on load-path.

This command sorts lines in the region between <var>start</var> and <var>end</var>, comparing them alphabetically by the <var>field</var>th field of each line. Fields are separated by whitespace and numbered starting from 1. If <var>field</var> is negative, sorting is by the -<var>field</var>th field from the end of the line. This command is useful for sorting tables.

This command sorts lines in the region between <var>start</var> and <var>end</var>, comparing them numerically by the <var>field</var>th field of each line. Fields are separated by whitespace and numbered starting from 1. The specified field must contain a number in each line of the region. Numbers starting with 0 are treated as octal, and numbers starting with ‘

This command sorts the lines in the region between <var>beg</var> and <var>end</var>, comparing them alphabetically by a certain range of columns. The column positions of <var>beg</var> and <var>end</var> bound the range of columns to sort on.

This command sorts the region between <var>start</var> and <var>end</var> alphabetically as specified by <var>record-regexp</var> and <var>key-regexp</var>. If <var>reverse</var> is a negative integer, then sorting is in reverse order.

This command specifies coding-system as the coding system to use for decoding keyboard input from terminal. If coding-system is nil, that means not to decode keyboard input. If terminal is a frame, it means that frame’s terminal; if it is nil, that means the currently selected frame’s terminal. See Multiple Terminals.

This command specifies coding-system as the coding system to use for encoding terminal output from terminal. If coding-system is nil, that means not to encode terminal output. If terminal is a frame, it means that frame’s terminal; if it is nil, that means the currently selected frame’s terminal.

This command swaps the states of the two live windows <var>window-1</var> and <var>window-2</var>. <var>window-1</var> must specify a live window and defaults to the selected one. <var>window-2</var> must specify a live window and defaults to the window following <var>window-1</var> in the cyclic ordering of windows, excluding minibuffer windows and including live windows on all visible frames.

This command switches to the last buffer in the local buffer list of the selected frame. More precisely, it calls the function switch-to-buffer (see Switching Buffers), to display the buffer returned by last-buffer (see above), in the selected window.

This command switches to the next buffer in window, thus undoing the effect of the last switch-to-prev-buffer command in window. The argument window must be a live window and defaults to the selected one.
This command toggles side windows on the specified <var>frame</var>. The optional argument <var>frame</var> must be a live frame and defaults to the selected one.
This command tries to work out appropriate settings to produce your preferred style of indentation. Simply call the command while visiting a file that is indented with your style.

This command unloads the library that provided feature feature. It undefines all functions, macros, and variables defined in that library with defun, defalias, defsubst, defmacro, defconst, defvar, and defcustom. It then restores any autoloads formerly associated with those symbols. (Loading saves these in the autoload property of the symbol.)
This command uses the functions posn-window and posn-point to determine where the click occurred, and dired-get-file-for-visit to determine which file to visit.

This command visits filename, like find-file does, but it does not perform any format conversions (see Format Conversion), character code conversions (see Coding Systems), or end-of-line conversions (see End of line conversion). The buffer visiting the file is made unibyte, and its major mode is Fundamental mode, regardless of the file name. File local variable specifications in the file (see File Local Variables) are ignored, and automatic decompression and adding a newline at the end of the file due to require-final-newline (see require-final-newline) are also disabled.

This command writes the current buffer contents into the file file in a format based on format, which is a list of format names. It constructs the actual format starting from format, then appending any elements from the value of buffer-file-format with a non-nilpreserve flag (see above), if they are not already present in format. It then updates buffer-file-format with this format, making it the default for future saves. Except for the format argument, this command is similar to write-file. In particular, confirm has the same meaning and interactive treatment as the corresponding argument to write-file. See Definition of write-file.
This command, bound to
This command, which is the default binding for
This completely replaces the old function with the new one. The old function can of course be recovered if you later call remove-function.
This constant is the name of the file where Emacs expects to find the directory-local variables. The name of the file is

This construct displays a message in the echo area temporarily, during the execution of <var>body</var>. It displays <var>message</var>, executes <var>body</var>, then returns the value of the last body form while restoring the previous echo area contents.

This construct does not actually match an argument. The element following :name should be a symbol; it is used as an additional name component for the definition. You can use this to add a unique, static component to the name of the definition. It may be used more than once.

This construct executes body once for each element of list, binding the variable var locally to hold the current element. Then it returns the value of evaluating result, or nil if result is omitted. For example, here is how you could use dolist to define the reverse function:

This construct executes body once for each integer from 0 (inclusive) to count (exclusive), binding the variable var to the integer for the current iteration. Then it returns the value of evaluating result, or nil if result is omitted. Use of result is deprecated. Here is an example of using dotimes to do something 100 times:

This construct executes body, ignoring any errors that occur during its execution. If the execution is without error, ignore-errors returns the value of the last form in body; otherwise, it returns nil.

This construct runs the body forms and returns the value of the last one—but only if no input arrives. If any input arrives during the execution of the body forms, it aborts them (working much like a quit). The while-no-input form returns nil if aborted by a real quit, and returns t if aborted by arrival of other input.

This constructs and returns a new ewoc, with no nodes (and thus no data elements). pretty-printer should be a function that takes one argument, a data element of the sort you plan to use in this ewoc, and inserts its textual description at point using insert (and never insert-before-markers, because that would interfere with the Ewoc package’s internal mechanisms).

This controls the way Edebug treats macro arguments with no explicit Edebug specification. If it is nil (the default), none of the arguments is instrumented for evaluation. Otherwise, all arguments are instrumented.
This convenience macro marks the function <var>obsolete-name</var> obsolete and also defines it as an alias for the function <var>current-name</var>. It is equivalent to the following:
This conversion applies only to characters, not to function keys or other input events; thus,
This convert the unibyte character <var>char</var> to a multibyte character, assuming <var>char</var> is either
This converts the multibyte character <var>char</var> to a unibyte character, and returns that character. If <var>char</var> is neither

This corresponds to __attribute__ ((__noinline__)) attribute of GCC, which prevents the function from being considered for inlining. This might be needed, e.g., to countermand effects of link-time optimizations on stack-based variables.
This could be buffer-local to do something special for specific files. If you change it, you may need to change backup-file-name-p and file-name-sans-versions too.

This could be implemented with multiple buffers (kept in sync when the user edits the text), or with narrowing (see Narrowing). But these alternatives might sometimes become tedious or prohibitively expensive, especially if each type of text requires expensive buffer-global operations in order to provide correct display and editing commands.
This creates an uninterned symbol named max and puts it in the expansion instead of the usual interned symbol max that appears in expressions ordinarily.
This creates and returns a display table. The table initially has nil in all elements.
This creates and returns an empty category table. In an empty category table, no categories have been allocated, and no characters belong to any categories.

This creates and returns an indirect buffer named <var>name</var> whose base buffer is <var>base-buffer</var>. The argument <var>base-buffer</var> may be a live buffer or the name (a string) of an existing buffer. If <var>name</var> is the name of an existing buffer, an error is signaled.

This creates and returns an xwidget object. If buffer is omitted or nil, it defaults to the current buffer. If buffer names a buffer that doesn’t exist, it will be created. The type identifies the type of the xwidget component, it can be one of the following:

This customizable option holds the default frame parameters used for displaying tooltips. Any font and color parameters are ignored, and the corresponding attributes of the tooltip face are used instead. If left or top parameters are included, they are used as absolute frame-relative coordinates where the tooltip should be shown. (Mouse-relative position of the tooltip can be customized using the variables described in Tooltips in

This customizable option holds the default frame parameters used for displaying tooltips. Any font and color parameters are ignored, and the corresponding attributes of the tooltip face are used instead. If left or top parameters are included, they are used as absolute frame-relative coordinates where the tooltip should be shown. (Mouse-relative position of the tooltip can be customized using the variables described in Tooltips in

This customization type is similar to alist (see above), except that (i) the information is stored as a property list, (see Property Lists), and (ii) key-type, if omitted, defaults to symbol rather than sexp.

This defines a global toggle named <var>global-mode</var> whose meaning is to enable or disable the buffer-local minor mode <var>mode</var> in all buffers. It also executes the <var>body</var> forms. To turn on the minor mode in a buffer, it uses the function <var>turn-on</var>; to turn off the minor mode, it calls <var>mode</var> with -1 as argument.

This defines a minor mode named “Hungry mode”, a command named hungry-mode to toggle it, a variable named hungry-mode which indicates whether the mode is enabled, and a variable named hungry-mode-map which holds the keymap that is active when the mode is enabled. It initializes the keymap with a key binding for
This defines a single Lisp form which is evaluated after the mode hooks have run. It should not be quoted.
This defines four comment-delimiting sequences:

This defines the customization option global-mode (see Customization), which can be toggled in the Customize interface to turn the minor mode on and off. As with define-minor-mode, you should ensure that the define-globalized-minor-mode form is evaluated each time Emacs starts, for example by providing a :require keyword.
This deletes each node in <var>nodes</var> from <var>ewoc</var>.
This deletes the file named filename, catching any error and returning nil if an error occurs. (You can use the macro ignore-errors for a simple case like this; see below.)

This determines the node in ewoc which contains point (or pos if specified), and returns that node. If ewoc has no nodes, it returns nil. If pos is before the first node, it returns the first node; if pos is after the last node, it returns the last node. The optional third arg guess should be a node that is likely to be near pos; this doesn’t alter the result, but makes the function run faster.
This differs from ordinary syntax such as this
This display action specifies the fallback behavior for display-buffer if no other display actions are given.

This display specification affects all the space characters within the text that has the specification. It displays all of these spaces <var>factor</var> times as wide as normal. The element <var>factor</var> should be an integer or float. Characters other than spaces are not affected at all; in particular, this has no effect on tab characters.
This display specification makes the text taller or shorter. Here are the possibilities for <var>height</var>:

This display specification on any character of a line of text causes the specified bitmap be displayed in the left or right fringes for that line, instead of the characters that have the display specification. The optional face specifies the face whose colors are to be used for the bitmap display. See Fringe Bitmaps, for the details.
This does for the size parameters height and width what the user-position parameter (see user-position) does for the position parameters top and left.
This does not depend on one of the libraries linked to Emacs.
This either tries to split the window at the bottom of the frame or the frame’s root window, or to reuse an existing window at the bottom of the selected frame.

This element is a boundary. The elements between two boundaries are called a change group; normally, each change group corresponds to one keyboard command, and undo commands normally undo an entire group as a unit.

This element of <var>spec</var> doesn’t match any terminal; instead, it specifies defaults that apply to all terminals. This element, if used, must be the first element of <var>spec</var>. Each of the following elements can override any or all of these defaults.
This element of spec matches all terminals. Therefore, any subsequent elements of spec are never used. Normally t is used in the last (or only) element of spec.
trans-unit.target: Este elemento de spec coincide con todos los terminales. Por lo tanto, los elementos posteriores de la spec nunca se utilizan. Normalmente t se utiliza en el último (o único) elemento de la spec .

trans-unit.source: This entry is similar to the window-height entry described before, but used to adjust the chosen window’s width instead. The value can be one of the following:
trans-unit.target: Esta entrada es similar a la entrada de window-height descrita anteriormente, pero se usa para ajustar el ancho de la ventana elegida. El valor puede ser uno de los siguientes:

trans-unit.source: This error can be handled through any of its condition names. This example handles new-error and any other errors in the class my-own-errors:
trans-unit.target: Este error se puede manejar mediante cualquiera de sus nombres de condición. Este ejemplo maneja new-error y cualquier otro error en la clase my-own-errors :

trans-unit.source: This error has several condition names: new-error, the narrowest classification; my-own-errors, which we imagine is a wider classification; and all the conditions of my-own-errors which should include error, which is the widest of all.
trans-unit.target: Este error tiene varios nombres de condición: new-error , la clasificación más estrecha; my-own-errors , que imaginamos es una clasificación más amplia; y todas las condiciones de my-own-errors que deberían incluir el error , que es el más amplio de todos.

trans-unit.source: This evaluates the arguments 1, (* 2 3), and (- 5 4) from left to right. Then it applies the lambda expression to the argument values 1, 6 and 1 to produce the value 8.
trans-unit.target: Esto evalúa los argumentos 1 , (* 2 3) y (- 5 4) de izquierda a derecha. Luego, aplica la expresión lambda a los valores de argumento 1, 6 y 1 para producir el valor 8.

trans-unit.source: This example affects only C mode proper. To add the same patterns to C mode and all modes derived from it, do this instead:
trans-unit.target: Este ejemplo afecta solo al modo C propiamente dicho. Para agregar los mismos patrones al modo C y todos los modos derivados de él, haga lo siguiente:

trans-unit.source: This example can be extended to be a color selection widget (in other words, the “controller” part of the “model–view–controller” design paradigm) by defining commands to modify colorcomp-data and to finish the selection process, and a keymap to tie it all together conveniently.
trans-unit.target: Este ejemplo puede extenderse para ser un widget de selección de color (en otras palabras, la parte "controlador" del paradigma de diseño "modelo-vista-controlador") definiendo comandos para modificar colorcomp-data y finalizar el proceso de selección, y un mapa de teclas para unirlo todo convenientemente.

trans-unit.source: This example creates a hash table whose keys are strings that are compared case-insensitively.
trans-unit.target: Este ejemplo crea una tabla de hash cuyas claves son cuerdas que se comparan sin tener en cuenta los casos.

trans-unit.source: This example creates a sparse keymap and makes a number of bindings in it:
trans-unit.target: Este ejemplo crea un mapa de teclas escaso y hace una serie de encuadernaciones en él:

trans-unit.source: This example has a small bug: if the user types
trans-unit.target: Este ejemplo tiene un pequeño error:si el usuario escribe

trans-unit.source: This example initializes the value of bar to 23, and gives it a documentation string:
trans-unit.target: Este ejemplo inicializa el valor de bar en 23 y le da una cadena de documentación:

trans-unit.source: This example shows how copy-alist makes it possible to change the associations of one copy without affecting the other:
trans-unit.target: Este ejemplo muestra cómo copy-alist hace posible cambiar las asociaciones de una copia sin afectar a la otra:

trans-unit.source: This example shows how to convert the window-relative coordinates in the text area of a window into frame-relative coordinates:
trans-unit.target: Este ejemplo muestra cómo convertir las coordenadas relativas a la ventana en el área de texto de una ventana en coordenadas relativas al marco:

trans-unit.source: This executes body normally, except any buffer changes it makes do not trigger the calls to before-change-functions and after-change-functions. Instead there is a single call of each of these hooks for the region enclosed by beg and end, the parameters supplied to after-change-functions reflecting the changes made to the size of the region by body.
trans-unit.target: Esto ejecuta body normalmente, excepto que cualquier cambio de búfer que haga no desencadena las llamadas a before-change-functions y after-change-functions . En su lugar, hay una única llamada de cada uno de estos ganchos para la región encerrada por beg y end , los parámetros suministrados a after-change-functions reflejan los cambios realizados en el tamaño de la región por body .

trans-unit.source: This exists as a separate function so that you can redefine it to customize the naming convention for auto-save files. Be sure to change auto-save-file-name-p in a corresponding way.
trans-unit.target: Esto existe como una función separada para que pueda redefinirla para personalizar la convención de nomenclatura para los archivos guardados automáticamente. Asegúrese de cambiar auto-save-file-name-p de la forma correspondiente.

trans-unit.source: This extracts the data encapsulated by <var>node</var> and returns it.
trans-unit.target: Esto extrae los datos encapsulados por <var>node</var> y los devuelve.

trans-unit.source: This feature has a drawback: if you delete, move, or alter the compiled file (such as by compiling a new version), Emacs may no longer be able to access the documentation string of previously-loaded functions or variables. Such a problem normally only occurs if you build Emacs yourself, and happen to edit and/or recompile the Lisp source files. To solve it, just reload each file after recompilation.
trans-unit.target: Esta característica tiene un inconveniente:si se borra,se mueve o se altera el archivo compilado (por ejemplo,compilando una nueva versión),es posible que Emacs ya no pueda acceder a la cadena de documentación de las funciones o variables cargadas anteriormente.Este problema normalmente sólo ocurre si construye Emacs usted mismo,y resulta que edita y/o recompila los archivos fuente de Lisp.Para solucionarlo,simplemente recarga cada archivo después de la recompilación.

trans-unit.source: This feature is particularly useful for macro definitions, since the arguments written in a macro definition often do not correspond to the way users think of the parts of the macro call.
trans-unit.target: Esta característica es particularmente útil para las definiciones de macro,ya que los argumentos escritos en una definición de macro a menudo no corresponden a la forma en que los usuarios piensan en las partes de la llamada macro.

trans-unit.source: This feature is typically used to give word syntax to characters which normally have symbol syntax, and thus to simplify imenu-generic-expression and speed up matching. For example, Fortran mode uses it this way:
trans-unit.target: Esta función se utiliza normalmente para dar sintaxis de palabras a caracteres que normalmente tienen sintaxis de símbolos y, por lo tanto, para simplificar imenu-generic-expression y acelerar la coincidencia. Por ejemplo, el modo Fortran lo usa de esta manera:

trans-unit.source: This feature is used in the mode line and for other active text.
trans-unit.target: Esta característica se utiliza en la línea de modo y para otros textos activos.

trans-unit.source: This field contains flags indicating that certain variables are local in this buffer. Such variables are declared in the C code using DEFVAR_PER_BUFFER, and their buffer-local bindings are stored in fields in the buffer structure itself. (Some of these fields are described in this table.)
trans-unit.target: Este campo contiene banderas que indican que ciertas variables son locales en este búfer. Dichas variables se declaran en el código C usando DEFVAR_PER_BUFFER , y sus enlaces locales al búfer se almacenan en campos en la estructura del búfer. (Algunos de estos campos se describen en esta tabla).

trans-unit.source: This field contains the value of cursor_off_p as of the time of the last redisplay.
trans-unit.target: Este campo contiene el valor de cursor_off_p en el momento de la última visualización.

trans-unit.source: This field holds the current overlay center position. See Managing Overlays.
trans-unit.target: Este campo contiene la posición central de superposición actual. Consulte Gestión de superposiciones .

trans-unit.source: This field is non-zero if the cursor is physically on.
trans-unit.target: Este campo es distinto de cero si el cursor está físicamente encendido.

trans-unit.source: This field is set to a non-zero value if window_end_pos and window_end_vpos are truly valid. This is zero if nontrivial redisplay is pre-empted, since in that case the display that window_end_pos was computed for did not get onto the screen.
trans-unit.target: Este campo se establece en un valor distinto de cero si window_end_pos y window_end_vpos son realmente válidos. Esto es cero si se reemplaza la visualización no trivial, ya que en ese caso la visualización para la que se calculó window_end_pos no apareció en la pantalla.

trans-unit.source: This flag causes any padding specified by the width to be inserted on the right rather than the left.
trans-unit.target: Esta bandera hace que cualquier acolchado especificado por el ancho se inserte a la derecha en lugar de a la izquierda.

trans-unit.source: This flag causes any padding specified by the width to consist of ‘
trans-unit.target: Esta bandera hace que cualquier relleno especificado por el ancho consista en '

trans-unit.source: This flag causes the substitution to be truncated on the left to the given width, if specified.
trans-unit.target: Esta bandera hace que la sustitución se trunque por la izquierda a la anchura dada,si se especifica.

trans-unit.source: This flag causes the substitution to be truncated on the right to the given width, if specified.
trans-unit.target: Esta bandera hace que la sustitución se trunque a la derecha a la anchura dada,si se especifica.

trans-unit.source: This flag converts the substituted text to lower case (see Case Conversion).
trans-unit.target: Esta bandera convierte el texto sustituido a minúsculas (consulte Conversión de mayúsculas y minúsculas ).

trans-unit.source: This flag converts the substituted text to upper case (see Case Conversion).
trans-unit.target: Esta bandera convierte el texto sustituido a mayúsculas (consulte Conversión de mayúsculas y minúsculas ).

trans-unit.source: This flag indicates that narrowing has changed in the buffer. See Narrowing.
trans-unit.target: Esta bandera indica que el estrechamiento ha cambiado en el búfer. Consulte Estrechamiento .

trans-unit.source: This flag indicates that redisplay optimizations should not be used to display this buffer.
trans-unit.target: Esta bandera indica que no se deben utilizar optimizaciones de visualización para mostrar este buffer.

trans-unit.source: This flag is t while loading all of the basic functions for building Emacs initially (allowing those functions to be shareable and non-collectible). Dumping Emacs as an executable always writes nil in this variable, regardless of the value it actually has before and after dumping.
trans-unit.target: Esta bandera es t mientras carga todas las funciones básicas para construir Emacs inicialmente (permitiendo que esas funciones sean compartibles y no coleccionables). El volcado de Emacs como ejecutable siempre escribe nil en esta variable, sin importar el valor que realmente tenga antes y después del volcado.

trans-unit.source: This form affects the sorting order for combining applicable methods. Normally, when two methods are compared during combination, method arguments are examined left to right, and the first method whose argument specializer is more specific will come before the other one. The order defined by this form overrides that, and the arguments are examined according to their order in this form, and not left to right.
trans-unit.target: Esta forma afecta al orden de clasificación para combinar los métodos aplicables.Normalmente,cuando se comparan dos métodos durante la combinación,los argumentos de los métodos se examinan de izquierda a derecha,y el primer método cuyo argumento especializado es más específico vendrá antes que el otro.El orden definido por esta forma lo anula,y los argumentos se examinan según su orden en esta forma,y no de izquierda a derecha.

trans-unit.source: This form defines a method like cl-defmethod does.
trans-unit.target: Este formulario define un método como lo hace cl-defmethod .

trans-unit.source: This form is rarely used and is now deprecated. Instead, you should write it as:
trans-unit.target: Esta forma se usa raramente y ahora está desaprobada.En su lugar,deberías escribirlo como:

trans-unit.source: This form marks <var>body</var> to be evaluated at compile time but not when the compiled program is loaded. The result of evaluation by the compiler becomes a constant which appears in the compiled program. If you load the source file, rather than compiling it, <var>body</var> is evaluated normally.
trans-unit.target: Este formulario marca el <var>body</var> para ser evaluado en tiempo de compilación pero no cuando se carga el programa compilado. El resultado de la evaluación del compilador se convierte en una constante que aparece en el programa compilado. Si carga el archivo fuente, en lugar de compilarlo, el <var>body</var> se evalúa normalmente.

trans-unit.source: This form marks <var>body</var> to be evaluated both when you compile the containing code and when you run it (whether compiled or not).
trans-unit.target: Este formulario marca el <var>body</var> para ser evaluado tanto cuando compila el código que lo contiene como cuando lo ejecuta (compilado o no).

trans-unit.source: This frame parameter controls the way the cursor looks.
trans-unit.target: Este parámetro del cuadro controla la forma en que el cursor se ve.

trans-unit.source: This function (un-)marks the height of window window as preserved for future resize operations. window must be a live window and defaults to the selected one. If the optional argument horizontal is non-nil, it (un-)marks the width of window as preserved.
trans-unit.target: Esta función (des-) marca la altura de la ventana de la window como preservada para futuras operaciones de cambio de tamaño. window debe ser una ventana en vivo y por defecto es la seleccionada. Si el argumento opcional horizontal no es nil , (des-) marca el ancho de la window como preservado.

trans-unit.source: This function warps the mouse to position x, y in frame frame. The arguments x and y are integers, giving the position in multiples of the default character size of frame (see Frame Font) relative to the native position of frame (see Frame Geometry).
trans-unit.target: Esta función deforma el mouse para colocar x , y en el marco del frame . Los argumentos x e y son números enteros, dando a la posición en múltiplos del tamaño de caracteres por defecto del frame (véase el marco de fuente ) con relación a la posición natural de frame (ver capítulo Geometría ).

trans-unit.source: This function aborts the command that requested the innermost recursive edit (including minibuffer input), by signaling quit after exiting the recursive edit. Its definition is effectively (throw 'exit t). See Quitting.
trans-unit.target: Esta función aborta el comando que solicitó la edición recursiva más interna (incluida la entrada del minibúfer), indicando quit después de salir de la edición recursiva. Su definición es efectivamente (throw 'exit t) . Consulte Salir .

trans-unit.source: This function accepts all the changes in the change group specified by <var>handle</var>, making them final.
trans-unit.target: Esta función acepta todos los cambios en el grupo de cambios especificado por <var>handle</var> , haciéndolos definitivos.

trans-unit.source: This function accesses selections set up by Emacs or by other programs. It takes two optional arguments, type and data-type. The default for type, the selection type, is PRIMARY.
trans-unit.target: Esta función accede a selecciones configuradas por Emacs o por otros programas. Toma dos argumentos opcionales, type y tipo de data-type . El type predeterminado , el tipo de selección, es PRIMARY .

trans-unit.source: This function activates the change group that <var>handle</var> designates.
trans-unit.target: Esta función activa el grupo de cambio que <var>handle</var> designa.

trans-unit.source: This function acts like eq except when both arguments are numbers. It compares numbers by type and numeric value, so that (eql 1.0 1) returns nil, but (eql 1.0 1.0) and (eql 1 1) both return t. This can be used to compare large integers as well as small ones.
trans-unit.target: Esta función actúa como eq excepto cuando ambos argumentos son números. Compara números por tipo y valor numérico, de modo que (eql 1.0 1) devuelve nil , pero (eql 1.0 1.0) y (eql 1 1) ambos devuelven t . Esto se puede utilizar para comparar enteros grandes y pequeños.

trans-unit.source: This function acts like format, except it also converts any grave accents (
trans-unit.target: Esta función actúa como format o , excepto que también convierte los acentos graves (

trans-unit.source: This function acts on the text between start and end, adding the face face to the face text property. face should be a valid value for the face property (see Special Properties), such as a face name or an anonymous face (see Faces).
trans-unit.target: Esta función actúa sobre el texto entre el start y el end , agregando la face a la propiedad del texto de la face . face debe ser un valor válido para la propiedad de la face (consulte Propiedades especiales ), como el nombre de una cara o una cara anónima (consulte Caras ).

trans-unit.source: This function actually uses the minibuffer, but does not allow editing of the answer. The cursor moves to the minibuffer while the question is being asked.
trans-unit.target: Esta función en realidad utiliza el minibúfer,pero no permite la edición de la respuesta.El cursor se mueve al minibúfer mientras se hace la pregunta.

trans-unit.source: This function adds keymap as a transient keymap, which takes precedence over other keymaps for one (or more) subsequent keys.
trans-unit.target: Esta función añade keymap como transitoria mapa de teclado, que tiene prioridad sobre otros mapas de caracteres de uno (o más) teclas siguientes.

trans-unit.source: This function adds rules as indentation rules for the current buffer. These add to any mode-specific rules defined by the smie-config option. To specify custom indentation rules for a specific file, add an entry to the file’s local variables of the form: eval: (smie-config-local '(rules)).
trans-unit.target: Esta función agrega rules como reglas de sangría para el búfer actual. Estos se suman a las reglas específicas del modo definidas por la opción smie-config . Para especificar reglas de sangría personalizadas para un archivo específico, agregue una entrada a las variables locales del archivo de la forma: eval: (smie-config-local '(rules)) .

trans-unit.source: This function adds a new element newelt, if it isn’t the empty string, to the history list stored in the variable history-var, and returns the updated history list. It limits the list length to the value of maxelt (if non-nil) or history-length (described below). The possible values of maxelt have the same meaning as the values of history-length. history-var cannot refer to a lexical variable.
trans-unit.target: Esta función agrega un nuevo elemento newelt , si no es la cadena vacía, a la lista de historial almacenada en la variable history-var , y devuelve la lista de historial actualizada. Limita la longitud de la lista al valor de maxelt (si no es nil ) o history-length (descrito a continuación). Los posibles valores de maxelt tienen el mismo significado que los valores de history-length . history-var no puede referirse a una variable léxica.

trans-unit.source: This function adds an item to the tool bar by modifying tool-bar-map. The image to use is defined by icon, which is the base name of an XPM, XBM or PBM image file to be located by find-image. Given a value ‘
trans-unit.target: Esta función agrega un elemento a la barra de tool-bar-map modificando tool-bar-map . La imagen que se va a utilizar se define mediante el icon o , que es el nombre base de un archivo de imagen XPM, XBM o PBM que se ubicará mediante find-image . Dado un valor '

trans-unit.source: This function adds highlighting keywords, for the current buffer or for major mode mode. The argument keywords should be a list with the same format as the variable font-lock-keywords.
trans-unit.target: Esta función añade destacando keywords , para el búfer actual o para el modo importante mode . Las keywords argumento deben ser una lista con el mismo formato que la variable font-lock-keywords .

trans-unit.source: This function adds its arguments together. When given no arguments, + returns 0.
trans-unit.target: Esta función suma sus argumentos. Cuando no se proporcionan argumentos, + devuelve 0.

trans-unit.source: This function adds or overrides text properties for the text between start and end in the string or buffer object. If object is nil, it defaults to the current buffer.
trans-unit.target: Esta función agrega o anula las propiedades de texto para el texto entre el start y el end de la cadena o el object búfer . Si el object es nil , toma como valor predeterminado el búfer actual.

trans-unit.source: This function adds the element element to buffer-invisibility-spec. If buffer-invisibility-spec was t, it changes to a list, (t), so that text whose invisible property is t remains invisible.
trans-unit.target: Esta función agrega el elemento element a buffer-invisibility-spec . Si buffer-invisibility-spec era t , cambia a una lista, (t) , de modo que el texto cuya propiedad invisible es t permanece invisible.

trans-unit.source: This function adds the face spec in <var>specs</var> as relative remappings for face <var>face</var> in the current buffer. The remaining arguments, <var>specs</var>, should form either a list of face names, or a property list of attribute/value pairs.
trans-unit.target: Esta función agrega la especificación de la cara en las <var>specs</var> como reasignaciones relativas para la <var>face</var> en el búfer actual. Los argumentos restantes, <var>specs</var> , deben formar una lista de nombres de caras o una lista de propiedades de pares de atributo / valor.

trans-unit.source: This function adjusts the current buffer’s auto-save file name if the visited file name has changed. It also renames an existing auto-save file, if it was made in the current Emacs session. If the visited file name has not changed, this function does nothing.
trans-unit.target: Esta función ajusta el nombre del archivo de guardado automático del búfer actual si el nombre del archivo visitado ha cambiado. También cambia el nombre de un archivo de guardado automático existente, si fue creado en la sesión actual de Emacs. Si el nombre del archivo visitado no ha cambiado, esta función no hace nada.

trans-unit.source: This function adjusts the indentation at the beginning of the current line to the value specified by the variable left-margin. (That may involve either inserting or deleting whitespace.) This function is value of indent-line-function in Paragraph-Indent Text mode.
trans-unit.target: Esta función ajusta la sangría al comienzo de la línea actual al valor especificado por la variable left-margin . (Eso puede implicar insertar o eliminar espacios en blanco.) Esta función es el valor de la función de indent-line-function de sangría en el modo Texto de sangría de párrafo.

trans-unit.source: This function allows Emacs to read pending output from processes. The output is given to their filter functions. If process is non-nil then this function does not return until some output has been received from process or process has closed the connection.
trans-unit.target: Esta función permite a Emacs leer la salida pendiente de los procesos. La salida se da a sus funciones de filtro. Si el process no es nil , esta función no regresa hasta que se haya recibido alguna salida del process o el process haya cerrado la conexión.

trans-unit.source: This function allows you to arrange that Emacs will ask the user for confirmation before exiting or before killing a buffer that has xwidget associated with it. If flag is non-nil, Emacs will query the user, otherwise it will not.
trans-unit.target: Esta función le permite hacer que Emacs le pida confirmación al usuario antes de salir o antes de matar un búfer que tiene xwidget asociado. Si flag no es nil , Emacs consultará al usuario, de lo contrario no lo hará.

trans-unit.source: This function also defines <var>face</var> as a valid face name if it is not already one, and (re)calculates its attributes on existing frames.
trans-unit.target: Esta función también define el <var>face</var> como un nombre de rostro válido si aún no lo es, y (re) calcula sus atributos en los marcos existentes.

trans-unit.source: This function also forces an update of the menu bar and frame title.
trans-unit.target: Esta función también obliga a actualizar la barra de menú y el título del marco.

trans-unit.source: This function also resets certain other information pertaining to the buffer: it sets the local keymap to nil, the syntax table to the value of (standard-syntax-table), the case table to (standard-case-table), and the abbrev table to the value of fundamental-mode-abbrev-table.
trans-unit.target: Esta función también restablece cierta otra información relacionada con el búfer: establece el mapa de teclas local en nil , la tabla de sintaxis en el valor de (standard-syntax-table) , la tabla de casos en (standard-case-table) tabla de casos estándar) y la abreviatura table al valor de fundamental-mode-abbrev-table .

trans-unit.source: This function also sets symbol as a variable, with the keymap as its value. But if mapvar is non-nil, it sets mapvar as a variable instead.
trans-unit.target: Esta función también establece el symbol como una variable, con el mapa de teclas como su valor. Pero si mapvar no es nil , establece mapvar como una variable en su lugar.

trans-unit.source: This function also signals an error if the buffer is an indirect buffer. An indirect buffer always inherits the representation of its base buffer.
trans-unit.target: Esta función también señala un error si el búfer es un búfer indirecto.Un búfer indirecto siempre hereda la representación de su búfer base.

trans-unit.source: This function alters part of the contents of the string <var>string</var>, by storing <var>obj</var> starting at index <var>idx</var>. The argument <var>obj</var> may be either a character or a (smaller) string.
trans-unit.target: Esta función altera parte del contenido de la <var>string</var> , almacenando <var>obj</var> comenzando en el índice <var>idx</var> . El argumento <var>obj</var> puede ser un carácter o una cadena (más pequeña).

trans-unit.source: This function alters the frame frame based on the elements of alist. Each element of alist has the form (parm . value), where parm is a symbol naming a parameter. If you don’t mention a parameter in alist, its value doesn’t change. If frame is nil, it defaults to the selected frame.
trans-unit.target: Esta función altera el marco del frame función de los elementos de una alist . Cada elemento de una alist tiene la forma (parm . value) , Donde parm es un símbolo que nombra un parámetro. Si no menciona un parámetro en una alist , su valor no cambia. Si el frame es nil , el valor predeterminado es el marco seleccionado.

trans-unit.source: This function alters the frame parameters of all existing frames according to alist, then modifies default-frame-alist (and, if necessary, initial-frame-alist) to apply the same parameter values to frames that will be created henceforth.
trans-unit.target: Esta función altera los parámetros del marco de todos los marcos existentes de acuerdo con una alist , luego modifica default-frame-alist (y, si es necesario, initial-frame-alist ) para aplicar los mismos valores de parámetro a los marcos que se crearán en adelante.

trans-unit.source: This function always returns nil. The old syntax information in the table for this character is discarded.
trans-unit.target: Esta función siempre devuelve nil . Se descarta la información de sintaxis antigua de la tabla para este carácter.

trans-unit.source: This function animates image. The optional integer index specifies the frame from which to start (default 0). The optional argument limit controls the length of the animation. If omitted or nil, the image animates once only; if t it loops forever; if a number animation stops after that many seconds.
trans-unit.target: Esta función anima la image n . El index enteros opcional especifica el marco desde el que comenzar (por defecto 0). El limit argumento opcional controla la duración de la animación. Si se omite o es nil , la imagen se anima una sola vez; si t se realiza un bucle para siempre; si una animación numérica se detiene después de esos segundos.

trans-unit.source: This function announces that <var>feature</var> is now loaded, or being loaded, into the current Emacs session. This means that the facilities associated with <var>feature</var> are or will be available for other Lisp programs.
trans-unit.target: Esta función anuncia que la <var>feature</var> ahora está cargada, o se está cargando, en la sesión actual de Emacs. Esto significa que las facilidades asociadas con la <var>feature</var> están o estarán disponibles para otros programas Lisp.

trans-unit.source: This function appends the contents of the region delimited by start and end in the current buffer to the end of file filename. If that file does not exist, it is created. This function returns nil.
trans-unit.target: Esta función agrega el contenido de la región delimitada por start y end en el búfer actual al final del filename del archivo . Si ese archivo no existe, se crea. Esta función devuelve nil .

trans-unit.source: This function appends the text string to the first entry in the kill ring and makes the yanking pointer point to the combined entry. Normally string goes at the end of the entry, but if before-p is non-nil, it goes at the beginning. This function calls kill-new as a subroutine, thus causing the values of interprogram-cut-function and possibly interprogram-paste-function (see below) to be invoked by extension.
trans-unit.target: Esta función agrega la string texto a la primera entrada del kill ring y hace que el puntero de extracción apunte a la entrada combinada. Normalmente, la string va al final de la entrada, pero si before-p no es nil , va al principio. Esta función llama a kill-new como una subrutina, lo que provoca que los valores de interprogram-cut-function y posiblemente interprogram-paste-function (ver más abajo) sean invocados por extensión.

trans-unit.source: This function applies <var>function</var> to each element of <var>sequence</var> in turn (presumably for side effects), and returns <var>sequence</var>.
trans-unit.target: Esta función aplica la <var>function</var> a cada elemento de la <var>sequence</var> por turno (presumiblemente para efectos secundarios) y devuelve la <var>sequence</var> .

trans-unit.source: This function applies function to each element of sequence, like mapcar, but instead of collecting the results into a list, it returns a single list with all the elements of the results (which must be lists), by altering the results (using nconc; see Rearrangement). Like with mapcar, sequence can be of any type except a char-table.
trans-unit.target: Esta función aplica la function a cada elemento de la sequence , como mapcar , pero en lugar de recopilar los resultados en una lista, devuelve una sola lista con todos los elementos de los resultados (que deben ser listas), alterando los resultados (usando nconc ; ver Reordenamiento ). Al igual que con mapcar , la sequence puede ser de cualquier tipo excepto una tabla de caracteres.

trans-unit.source: This function applies spec as a face spec for face. spec should be a face spec, as described in the above documentation for defface.
trans-unit.target: Esta función aplica la spec como especificación de face para cara . spec debe ser una especificación de cara, como se describe en la documentación anterior para defface .

trans-unit.source: This function applies a translation table to the characters in the buffer between positions <var>start</var> and <var>end</var>.
trans-unit.target: Esta función aplica una tabla de traducción a los caracteres en el búfer entre las posiciones <var>start</var> y <var>end</var> .

trans-unit.source: This function arranges for watch-function to be called whenever symbol is modified. Modifications through aliases (see Variable Aliases) will have the same effect.
trans-unit.target: Esta función hace que se llame a la watch-function de reloj siempre que se modifique el symbol . Las modificaciones a través de alias (consulte Alias ​​de variables ) tendrán el mismo efecto.

trans-unit.source: This function arranges for the debugger to be called whenever <var>variable</var> is modified.
trans-unit.target: Esta función hace que se llame al depurador siempre <var>variable</var> se modifique la variable .

trans-unit.source: This function asks the user a question, expecting input in the minibuffer. It returns t if the user enters ‘
trans-unit.target: Esta función le hace una pregunta al usuario, esperando entrada en el minibúfer. Devuelve t si el usuario ingresa '

trans-unit.source: This function asks the user a question, expecting input in the minibuffer. It returns t if the user types
trans-unit.target: Esta función le hace una pregunta al usuario, esperando entrada en el minibúfer. Devuelve t si el usuario escribe

trans-unit.source: This function asks the user a series of questions, reading a single-character answer in the echo area for each one.
trans-unit.target: Esta función hace al usuario una serie de preguntas,leyendo una respuesta de un solo carácter en el área de eco para cada una.

trans-unit.source: This function assigns class to all the files in directory and its subdirectories. Thereafter, all the variable settings specified for class will be applied to any visited file in directory and its children. class must have been already defined by dir-locals-set-class-variables.
trans-unit.target: Esta función asigna class a todos los archivos en el directory y sus subdirectorios. A partir de entonces, todas las configuraciones de variables especificadas para la class se aplicarán a cualquier archivo visitado en el directory y sus hijos. class debe haber sido definida por dir-locals-set-class-variables .

trans-unit.source: This function assigns profiles, which are symbols, to all remote connections identified by criteria. criteria is a plist identifying a connection and the application using this connection. Property names might be :application, :protocol, :user and :machine. The property value of :application is a symbol, all other property values are strings. All properties are optional; if criteria is nil, it always applies. Example:
trans-unit.target: Esta función asigna profiles , que son símbolos, a todas las conexiones remotas identificadas por criteria . criteria es una lista que identifica una conexión y la aplicación que usa esta conexión. Los nombres de propiedades podrían ser :application , :protocol o , :user y :machine . El valor de propiedad de :application es un símbolo, todos los demás valores de propiedad son cadenas. Todas las propiedades son opcionales; si el criteria es nil , siempre se aplica. Ejemplo:

trans-unit.source: This function associates sentinel with process. If sentinel is nil, then the process will have the default sentinel, which inserts a message in the process’s buffer when the process status changes.
trans-unit.target: Esta función asocia sentinel con process . Si sentinel es nil , entonces el proceso tendrá el centinela predeterminado, que inserta un mensaje en el búfer del proceso cuando cambia el estado del proceso.

trans-unit.source: This function associates the color name <var>name</var> with color number <var>number</var> on the terminal.
trans-unit.target: Esta función asocia el nombre del color <var>name</var> con el número del color <var>number</var> en el terminal.

trans-unit.source: This function attempts to give all windows on the selected frame approximately the same share of the screen area. Full-width or full-height windows are not given more space than other windows.
trans-unit.target: Esta función intenta dar a todas las ventanas del marco seleccionado aproximadamente la misma parte del área de la pantalla.A las ventanas de ancho o alto completo no se les da más espacio que a otras ventanas.

trans-unit.source: This function attempts to keep point, markers, text properties, and overlays in the current buffer intact. One potential case where this behavior is useful is external code formatting programs: they typically write the reformatted text into a temporary buffer or file, and using delete-region and insert-buffer-substring would destroy these properties. However, the latter combination is typically faster (See Deletion, and Insertion).
trans-unit.target: Esta función intenta mantener intactos los puntos, marcadores, propiedades del texto y superposiciones en el búfer actual. Un caso potencial en el que este comportamiento es útil son los programas de formato de código externo: normalmente escriben el texto reformateado en un búfer o archivo temporal, y el uso de delete-region e insert-buffer-substring destruiría estas propiedades. Sin embargo, la última combinación suele ser más rápida (consulte Eliminación e inserción ).

trans-unit.source: This function attempts to make window as large as possible, in both dimensions, without resizing its frame or deleting other windows. If window is omitted or nil, it defaults to the selected window.
trans-unit.target: Esta función intenta hacer la window más grande posible, en ambas dimensiones, sin cambiar el tamaño de su marco ni eliminar otras ventanas. Si la window se omite o es nil , por defecto es la ventana seleccionada.

trans-unit.source: This function attempts to make window as small as possible, in both dimensions, without deleting it or resizing its frame. If window is omitted or nil, it defaults to the selected window.
trans-unit.target: Esta función intenta hacer la window más pequeña posible, en ambas dimensiones, sin borrarla ni redimensionar su marco. Si la window se omite o es nil , por defecto es la ventana seleccionada.

trans-unit.source: This function auto-saves all buffers that need to be auto-saved. It saves all buffers for which auto-saving is enabled and that have been changed since the previous auto-save.
trans-unit.target: Esta función guarda automáticamente todos los buffers que necesitan ser guardados automáticamente.Guarda todos los buffers para los que el auto-guardado está habilitado y que han sido cambiados desde el auto-guardado anterior.

trans-unit.source: This function balances windows in a way that gives more space to full-width and/or full-height windows. If window-or-frame specifies a frame, it balances all windows on that frame. If window-or-frame specifies a window, it balances only that window and its siblings (see Windows and Frames).
trans-unit.target: Esta función equilibra las ventanas de una manera que da más espacio a las ventanas de ancho completo y / o altura completa. Si window-or-frame especifica un marco, equilibra todas las ventanas en ese marco. Si window-or-frame especifica una ventana, equilibra solo esa ventana y sus hermanas (consulte Ventanas y marcos ).

trans-unit.source: This function beeps, or flashes the screen (see visible-bell below). It also terminates any keyboard macro currently executing unless do-not-terminate is non-nil.
trans-unit.target: Esta función emite un pitido o hace parpadear la pantalla (consulte visible-bell continuación). También finaliza cualquier macro de teclado que se esté ejecutando actualmente, a menos que do-not-terminate no sea nil .

trans-unit.source: This function behaves exactly like error, except that it uses the error symbol user-error rather than error. As the name suggests, this is intended to report errors on the part of the user, rather than errors in the code itself. For example, if you try to use the command Info-history-back (
trans-unit.target: Esta función se comporta exactamente como error , excepto que utiliza el símbolo de error error de user-error lugar de error . Como sugiere el nombre, esto está destinado a informar errores por parte del usuario, en lugar de errores en el código en sí. Por ejemplo, si intenta utilizar el comando Info-history-back (

trans-unit.source: This function behaves like custom-initialize-set, but it delays the actual initialization to the next Emacs start. This should be used in files that are preloaded (or for autoloaded variables), so that the initialization is done in the run-time context rather than the build-time context. This also has the side-effect that the (delayed) initialization is performed with the :set function. See Building Emacs.
trans-unit.target: Esta función se comporta como custom-initialize-set , pero retrasa la inicialización real hasta el siguiente inicio de Emacs. Esto debe usarse en archivos que están precargados (o para variables autocargadas), de modo que la inicialización se realice en el contexto de tiempo de ejecución en lugar del contexto de tiempo de compilación. Esto también tiene el efecto secundario de que la inicialización (retrasada) se realiza con la función :set . Consulte Creación de Emacs .

trans-unit.source: This function behaves like equal in all cases but also requires that for two strings to be equal, they have the same text properties.
trans-unit.target: Esta función se comporta como equal en todos los casos, pero también requiere que para que dos cadenas sean iguales, tengan las mismas propiedades de texto.

trans-unit.source: This function browses the specified <var>uri</var> in the given <var>xwidget</var>. The <var>uri</var> is a string that specifies the name of a file or a URL.
trans-unit.target: Esta función examina el <var>uri</var> especificado en el <var>xwidget</var> dado . El <var>uri</var> es una cadena que especifica el nombre de un archivo o una URL.

trans-unit.source: This function builds a prec2 table from a table of precedences precs. precs should be a list, sorted by precedence (for example "+" will come before "*"), of elements of the form (assoc op ...), where each op is a token that acts as an operator; assoc is their associativity, which can be either left, right, assoc, or nonassoc. All operators in a given element share the same precedence level and associativity.

This function byte-compiles the function definition of symbol, replacing the previous definition with the compiled one. The function definition of symbol must be the actual code for the function; byte-compile does not handle function indirection. The return value is the byte-code function object which is the compiled definition of symbol (see Byte-Code Objects).

This function calculates the dimensions of the largest empty rectangle that can be inscribed in the specified <var>window</var>’s text area. <var>window</var> must be a live window and defaults to the selected one.

This function calculates the pixel dimensions of each line displayed in the specified window. It does so by walking window’s current glyph matrix—a matrix storing the glyph (see Glyphs) of each buffer character currently displayed in window. If successful, it returns a list of cons pairs representing the x- and y-coordinates of the lower right corner of the last character of each line. Coordinates are measured in pixels from an origin (0, 0) at the top-left corner of window. window must be a live window and defaults to the selected one.

This function calls describe-bindings to display a list of all the subcommands of the prefix key of the most recent key sequence. The prefix described consists of all but the last event of that key sequence. (The last event is, presumably, the help character.)
This function calls progress-reporter-update, so the first message is printed immediately.
This function calls replace-buffer-in-windows for cleaning up all windows currently displaying the buffer to be killed.
This function calls function once for each of the associations in table. The function function should accept two arguments—a key listed in table, and its associated value. maphash returns nil.
This function calls function once with each symbol in the obarray obarray. Then it returns nil. If obarray is omitted, it defaults to the value of obarray, the standard obarray for ordinary symbols.
This function calls <var>program</var> and waits for it to finish.

This function calls its argument function for each element of char-table that has a non-nil value. The call to function is with two arguments, a key and a value. The key is a possible range argument for char-table-range—either a valid character or a cons cell (from . to), specifying a range of characters that share the same value. The value is what (char-table-range char-table key) returns.
This function calls the function <var>fun</var> once for each live window, with the window as the argument.

This function calls the function predicate for each of the windows in the cyclic order of windows in turn, passing it the window as an argument. If the predicate returns non-nil for any window, this function stops and returns that window. If no such window is found, the return value is default (which defaults to nil).
This function calls the interactively callable function <var>command</var>, providing arguments according to its interactive calling specifications. It returns whatever <var>command</var> returns.

This function calls the specified func passing it nargs arguments from the array pointed to by args. The argument func can be a function symbol (e.g., returned by intern described above), a module function returned by make_function (see Module Functions), a subroutine written in C, etc. If nargs is zero, args can be a NULL pointer.
This function can also be called interactively. In that case, it prints a message reporting the number of lines, words, and characters in the buffer, or in the region if the region is active.
This function can be called before an amalgamating command. It removes the previous undo-boundary if a series of such calls have been made.

This function can be used to initialize the local keymap of a major mode for which insertion of text is not desirable. But usually such a mode should be derived from special-mode (see Basic Major Modes); then its keymap will automatically inherit from special-mode-map, which is already suppressed. Here is how special-mode-map is defined:
This function can be used to transpose stretches of text:
This function can be useful as an output stream when debugging. It writes <var>character</var> to the standard error stream.
This function can indicate there are no more sort records by leaving point at the end of the buffer.
This function cancels and undoes all the changes in the change group specified by <var>handle</var>.
This function cancels any narrowing in the current buffer, so that the entire contents are accessible. This is called widening. It is equivalent to the following expression:
This function cannot be used in an Emacs that was already dumped. This function is deprecated, and by default Emacs is built without unexec support so this function is not available.
This function cannot tell whether the comments it traverses are embedded within a string. If they look like comments, it treats them as comments.

This function capitalizes count words after point, moving point over as it does. To capitalize means to convert each word’s first character to upper case and convert the rest of each word to lower case. If count is negative, the function capitalizes the -count previous words but does not move point. The value is nil.

This function capitalizes all words in the region defined by start and end. To capitalize means to convert each word’s first character to upper case and convert the rest of each word to lower case. The function returns nil.

This function capitalizes strings or characters. If <var>string-or-char</var> is a string, the function returns a new string whose contents are a copy of <var>string-or-char</var> in which each word has been capitalized. This means that the first character of each word is converted to upper case, and the rest are converted to lower case.
This function causes the browser widget specified by xwidget to execute the specified JavaScript script.

This function changes the contents of the full keymap keymap by remapping self-insert-command to the command undefined (see Remapping Commands). This has the effect of undefining all printing characters, thus making ordinary insertion of text impossible. suppress-keymap returns nil.
This function changes the finalizer of the user-ptr object represented by val to be fin. If fin is a NULL pointer, the user-ptr object will have no finalizer.

This function changes the tabulated list entry at point, setting col to desc. col is the column number to change, or the name of the column to change. desc is the new column descriptor, which is inserted via tabulated-list-print-col.

This function checks the file contents against the defined file formats, and converts the file contents if appropriate and also calls the functions in the list after-insert-file-functions. See Format Conversion. Normally, one of the functions in the after-insert-file-functions list determines the coding system (see Coding Systems) used for decoding the file’s contents, including end-of-line conversion. However, if the file contains null bytes, it is by default visited without any code conversions. See inhibit-nul-byte-detection.

This function checks the validity of coding-system. If that is valid, it returns coding-system. If coding-system is nil, the function return nil. For any other values, it signals an error whose error-symbol is coding-system-error (see signal).
This function checks whether feature is present in the current Emacs session (using (featurep feature); see below). The argument feature must be a symbol.

This function checks whether sequence1 and sequence2 contain the same elements, regardless of the order. If the optional argument testfn is non-nil, it is a function of two arguments to use instead of the default equal.

This function checks whether a window <var>window</var> occupies the frame relative coordinates <var>coordinates</var>, and if so, which part of the window that is. <var>window</var> should be a live window.

This function checks whether coding systems in the list coding-system-list can encode all the characters in the region between start and end. If all of the coding systems in the list can encode the specified text, the function returns nil. If some coding systems cannot encode some of the characters, the value is an alist, each element of which has the form (coding-system1 pos1 pos2 …), meaning that coding-system1 cannot encode characters at buffer positions pos1, pos2, ....
This function chooses a plausible coding system for decoding the text from <var>start</var> to <var>end</var>. This text should be a byte sequence, i.e., unibyte text or multibyte text with only
This function clears all tags from the padding area in the current buffer.

This function clears an image cache, removing all the images stored in it. If filter is omitted or nil, it clears the cache for the selected frame. If filter is a frame, it clears the cache for that frame. If filter is t, all image caches are cleared. Otherwise, filter is taken to be a file name, and all images associated with that file name are removed from all image caches.
This function clears and redisplays all visible frames.
This function clears and redisplays frame frame. If frame is omitted or nil, it redraws the selected frame.

This function clears out the record of the last modification time of the file being visited by the current buffer. As a result, the next attempt to save this buffer will not complain of a discrepancy in file modification times.
This function clears the pending nonlocal exit conditions and data from <var>env</var>. After calling it, the module
This function clears the table of defined colors for a text terminal.
This function closes a notification with identifier id. bus can be a string denoting a D-Bus connection, the default is :session.
This function closes the connection to display display. Before you can do this, you must first delete all the frames that were open on that display (see Deleting Frames).
This function collects applicable connection-local variables associated with criteria in connection-local-variables-alist, without applying them. Example:

This function compares a specified part of string1 with a specified part of string2. The specified part of string1 runs from index start1 (inclusive) up to index end1 (exclusive); nil for start1 means the start of the string, while nil for end1 means the length of the string. Likewise, the specified part of string2 runs from index start2 up to index end2.
This function compares strings lexicographically, except it treats sequences of numerical characters as if they comprised a base-ten number, and then compares the numbers. So ‘

This function compares two strings a character at a time. It scans both the strings at the same time to find the first pair of corresponding characters that do not match. If the lesser character of these two is the character from string1, then string1 is less, and this function returns t. If the lesser character is the one from string2, then string1 is greater, and this function returns nil. If the two strings match entirely, the value is nil.
This function compares two window configurations as regards the structure of windows, but ignores the values of point and the saved scrolling positions—it can return t even if those aspects differ.

This function compares what <var>buffer</var> (by default, the current-buffer) has recorded for the modification time of its visited file against the actual modification time of the file as recorded by the operating system. The two should be the same unless some other process has written the file since Emacs visited or saved it.
This function compiles a file of Lisp code named <var>filename</var> into a file of byte-code. The output file’s name is made by changing the ‘
This function completely replaces the text property list for the text between start and end in the string or buffer object. If object is nil, it defaults to the current buffer.

This function completes the file name filename in directory directory. It returns the longest prefix common to all file names in directory directory that start with filename. If predicate is non-nil then it ignores possible completions that don’t satisfy predicate, after calling that function with one argument, the expanded absolute file name.
This function completes the minibuffer contents as far as possible.

This function completes the minibuffer contents by at most a single word. Even if the minibuffer contents have only one completion, minibuffer-complete-word does not add any characters beyond the first character that is not a word constituent. See Syntax Tables.

This function completes the minibuffer contents, and exits if confirmation is not required, i.e., if minibuffer-completion-confirm is nil. If confirmation is required, it is given by repeating this command immediately—the command is programmed to work without confirmation when run twice in succession.
This function completes the text in the current buffer between the positions start and end, using collection. The argument collection has the same meaning as in try-completion (see Basic Completion).
This function computes and sets header-line-format for the Tabulated List buffer (see Header Lines), and assigns a keymap to the header line to allow sorting entries by clicking on column headers.

This function computes the file name for a new backup file for filename. It may also propose certain existing backup files for deletion. find-backup-file-name returns a list whose CAR is the name for the new backup file and whose CDR is a list of backup files whose deletion is proposed. The value can also be nil, which means not to make a backup.

This function concatenates list-of-strings into a single string, quoting each string as necessary. It also sticks the separator string between each pair of strings; if separator is omitted or nil, it defaults to " ". The return value is the resulting string.
This function concatenates all its argument <var>bytes</var> and makes the result a unibyte string.

This function configures a serial port connection. Arguments are specified as keyword/argument pairs. Attributes that are not given are re-initialized from the process’s current configuration (available via the function process-contact), or set to reasonable default values. The following arguments are defined:

This function considers only vertical scrolling. If position is out of view only because window has been scrolled horizontally, pos-visible-in-window-p returns non-nil anyway. See Horizontal Scrolling.

This function constrains <var>new-pos</var> to the field that <var>old-pos</var> belongs to—in other words, it returns the position closest to <var>new-pos</var> that is in the same field as <var>old-pos</var>.
